description:
Cokeromyces recurvatus is a species of fungus that belongs to the Zygomycota phylum. It is a member of the Mucorales order and the Choanephoraceae family. The species is known for its unique and characteristic morphological features.

Cokeromyces recurvatus is a filamentous fungus that grows as a white, cottony colony on various substrates. The hyphae, which are the main vegetative structures of the fungus, are septate and branched. The most distinctive feature of this species is the presence of recurved sporangiophores, which are the specialized structures that bear the sporangia (spore-containing structures).

The sporangiophores of Cokeromyces recurvatus are erect, slender, and typically curved or bent back upon themselves, giving the fungus a characteristic appearance. The sporangia are spherical, dark-colored, and contain numerous small, round spores called sporangiospores.

Cokeromyces recurvatus is commonly found in soil and decaying organic matter, and it is known to play a role in the decomposition of various plant materials. The species has been studied for its potential applications in biotechnology and environmental remediation due to its unique metabolic capabilities.
